However, while the approximate $1 trillion of student debt would require a significant amount of tax funds, an attempt to make education affordable, or at least to reduce the impact of the debt upon the student, would allow the student to better establish themselves in society before being overwhelmed by an onslaught of college debt; a system that has established and evidently benefitted the youth of the United Kingdom. In the United States, our current system of secondary education discourages disadvantaged or even middle-class youth from pursuing an education, and this unequal opprotunity created by the fear of formidable debt does not represent progressive, equitable values that are upheld by traditional American values. The $1 trillion in student debt is, indisputably, a more progressive and worthwhile contribution to the nation than other recipients of tax funds such as military equipment and foreign military occupancy, which represents over $13 trillion of US debt. Education, overall, is the strongest creator of equality and progressive action to American citizens, and should be protected and encouraged.

data_answer: Opponents of the proposal calling for debt forgiveness contend that giving students amnesty for college loans will have several adverse effects. For example, it is believed that debt forgiveness would set a precedent that similar loans in the future will also be forgiven. This would encourage students to spend money on frivolous items and not on their tuition. In addition, about $1 trillion of student debt is in federal student loans, meaning that US taxpayers are paying for students' debt rather than the students and their families. Furthermore, the cost of public four-year college tuition has grown rapidly by 357%. This would mean that taxpayers will have to pay even more money in the future, assuming this trend continues. Overall, the forgiveness of debts, would have a very taxing effect on American taxpayers.

data_answer: There will be more pros than cons if college students were given debt forgiveness. One of the major negative effects would be that college students won't have the responsibility of having to pay their debts; instead, they "spend money on frivolous items, not on tuition", notes one credible source. Since college students are just moved out and have a newfound freedom, they aren't going to be spending their money wisely-and that's when they have tuition to pay. Imagine if they didn't have to pay that $20,000 a year-they'd be going crazy with all that money! Giving college students debt forgiveness won't be a good idea because they won't spend the money properly. In addition, the colleges themselves will be is tremendous debt if they paid for their students' tuition. And who pays for this debt? The taxpayers do. According to another highly credible source "about $1 trillion of the current $1.2 trillion in student debt is in federal student loans/this means US taxpayers are paying for students' debt rather than students and families". This upsets many of the taxpayers because this money should be going to public projects that will benefit ALL of the community, not just a small portion of it. Some would say giving debt forgiveness is a great idea. They say it would promote more attending college. But it's not a good idea because more and more state debt would be accumulated.

data_answer: While this program does have its merits, it also has several downsides. If the debt is forgiven as suggested by the program, it will set a precedent for incoming students, leading them to believe that their debt will be forgiven as well. This will cause them to spend even more money because they think they won't be held accountable for it. There is also a concern that the money that would have been used for tuition will then be used towards the purchase of frivolous items. Finally, there is the obvious concern of who will be paying for these forgiven loans. Currently, about $1 trillion of $1.2 trillion in student debt is in federal student loans, which means that US taxpayers are paying for students' debt. These taxpayers would be hit the hardest if the loans were forgiven, because taxes will have to continue to raise if this program is to remain sustainable.

data_answer: The opposition states that there are multiple potential problems, two of which are the main basis of their arguments. They say that debt forgiveness promotes accumulating more debt, and that when they receive amnesty, it will also promote frivolity and the students will spend money on things other than their tuition. These would be valid, and very persuasive, points if it were true that students are the ones who pay off most of their debt. However, out of the current student debt of $1.2 trillion, $1 trillion of it is in federal student loans. That means that U.S. taxpayer dollars are paying for the majority of debt students accumulate. Also, if the students are required to pay off their debts, they will only dig themselves deeper into debt. In the last 30 years, the average cost of tuition for a public 4-year institution has grown by 357 percent, this means that the students accumalative debt will only compound if they are forced to pay it. They are then left with a continuing trend of debt that lasts much longer than college and affects their whole lives. If, however, they are given amnesty on their debts, they remain to live debt free and accomplish the great goal of the American dream.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: Giving currently enrolled students with high grade-point averages amnesty for college loans will undoubtedly have undesirable consequences. Firstly, if the nation eliminates these debts now, it insinuates to future college applicants that the same policy will be in place in later years, setting an unfair precedent that may be impossible to maintain. Furthermore, if students are provided with the money that they would have spent on tuition, and are told that they may use it in any way that suits them, the money will likely be spent carelessly on materialistic and unimportant items, degrading the youth's perception of the value and importance of money. Also, roughly $1 trillion of the current $1.2 trillion dollars in student debt is being paid for on a federal level, with American taxpayer's dollars. Such a hefty financial burden should not be placed on US society as a whole, but rather the people to whom it belongs. Providing today's youth with the mentality that their debts can be wiped clean will not instill in them the drive or desire to work hard; it will encourage laziness and prevent many young people from appreciating the education they are being provided with, regardless of their financial situation.

data_answer: Although there are many benefits to enforcing the use of the amnesty program in the US, there are many potential problems that can result from its enforcement. One specific consequence of this amnesty is how it will set a precedent for similar loans in the future. The student may believe that future loans will be forgiven, and, therefore, will accumulate additional college debt. This means that students following this precedent will believe that they accumulate large debts and take more expensive items without fear. A second unintended result of this amnesty is that some students may choose to spend their money on unnecessary items instead of on tuition. They will be extending their loans for something not related to their education even though the purpose of granting amnesty is to allow the students additional educational opportunities. Statistics show that in the last 30 years, the cost of a four-year college tuition has grown rapidly by about 357 percent. By these results, the introduction of the student amnesty program will set a new trend. That is, students will get debt amnesty and will not have to pay for college loans. By introducing the new program, the college will need to beware of the various consequences that may occur.
